Whenever a thought or intention arises, you must **uphold sincerity and reverence** (存诚主敬), **examine and reflect inwardly** (暗自端详), **inspect and correct yourself** (省察提撕), and **maintain central rectitude** (大中正直). Sweep away the **pensive thoughts** (念头) in your heart, making it **spotlessly pure** (清清净净). Like the **verdant sky and radiant moon**, there is not a trace of clouds or shadows; like **crystal and polished glass**, there is not a speck of blemish; like **limitless bright mirrors**, there is not a particle of dust; like **night-pearls** (夜明珠), there is not a thread of darkness. Steady and round, **radiant and resplendent** (光灿灿), one may then **deliver the Dao** (讲道). **Wisdom and radiance** (智慧光明), **true void’s marvelous form** (真空妙相), all arise from **precepts and concentration** (戒定).

Through **enduring humiliation and severing obstacles**, with **precepts strict and refined**, through **self-discipline and rigorous cultivation**, aided by **dharma-pharmaceuticals**, one may attain this state. Yet if one **holds precepts loosely**, few can truly uphold them—**practicing secretly yet deceptively**, never truly ceasing even a fraction.

Why? **O foolish disciples**, if one’s **conduct is not secret**, it is called the **cause of defilement**—how then could one **realize the fruit of non-doing**?

These four words—**wisdom and radiance**—are the **highest rank of sharp faculties**. Thus, the **lowest rank of dull faculties** cannot penetrate them. Only by **unwavering resolve**, **concentrating qi at the acupoints**, **nurturing ancestral qi**, **nourishing primordial nature**, reaching **ultimate emptiness**, **steadfastly abiding in stillness**, **remaining pure and undivided**, **hiding the spirit in the boundless**, and **returning to the Great Polarity**, will **wisdom and radiance naturally arise**, as **one yang revives**—only then does one **see the original face**.

To **know the nature of spirits and gods**, to **grasp the mechanisms of transformation**—this is **wisdom**; to **participate in heaven and earth’s nurturing**, to **align with the sun and moon’s succession**, to **harmonize with the four seasons’ cycles**—this is **wisdom**; to **universally manifest the dharma-body**, to **subdue the dharma-realm within awareness**, never straying from **enlightenment’s illumination**, all returning to **the radiant void**—this is **radiance**; to **penetrate all things in formlessness**, to **foresee all matters before their signs**, to **pervade the void without trace**, to **transcend sun and moon without shadow**—this is **clarity**.

If one’s **precepts are not precise**, one cannot attain **serene composure**. Without **serene composure**, **wisdom does not arise**. Without **wisdom**, **radiance does not manifest**.

The *Jade Pivot Treasure Scripture* in one scroll **directly points to human nature**, **unveiling innate truth**, **laying bare celestial mechanisms**, enabling beings to **turn the scripture and awaken to the Way**. Yet alas, the **bewildered outnumber the enlightened**. They **recite with their mouths but cannot uphold with their hearts**; their **hearts may be sincere, yet their strength cannot transform**.

What a pity—**they squander the sage’s intent**, **wasting the sacred treasure**. Now I must **interpret the scripture’s marvels**, **point to the true mechanism**, so that you may **suddenly awaken**.

All of you, **revere and listen with earnest intent**. The scripture says:

*"In the past, fifteen thousand kalpas ago, my heart encountered this Dao, and I attained the rank of Highest Truth. My intention cultivated this merit, and I thus governed the Great Transformation."*

Again it says:
*"With a serene mind, I vowed a boundless aspiration; with wisdom’s power, I subdued all demons."*

Again it says:
*"You heavenly and human beings who wish to hear the supreme Dao—
The supreme Dao is profound and distant, not found elsewhere.
If you truly wish to hear it, **‘without interruption’ is the key.
Without interruption, without perception—this is the true Dao.
Even perception fades; only you remain.
You are not yet ‘having’—how much less the Dao?
To hear without hearing—what Dao is there to discuss?"*

Again it says:
*"The Dao is entered with **sincerity**, guarded with **silence**, and applied with **gentleness**.
To use sincerity seems foolish,
To use silence seems inarticulate,
To use gentleness seems clumsy.
Thus, one may **forget form**, **forget self**, **forget forgetting**.
Those who enter the Dao **know when to stop**,
Those who guard the Dao **know caution**,
Those who apply the Dao **know subtlety**.
To know subtlety, wisdom’s radiance arises;
To know caution, sacred wisdom is complete;
To know when to stop, serene composure is secure.
Serene composure ensures sacred wisdom’s completeness,
Sacred wisdom’s completeness brings wisdom’s radiance,
Wisdom’s radiance unites with the Dao—
This is called **true forgetting**.
Forgetting yet not forgetting,
Nothing left to forget—
That which cannot be forgotten **is the supreme Dao**.
The Dao is in heaven and earth,
Yet heaven and earth do not know it;
Sentient and insentient alike—
It is **one and undivided**."*

Again it says:
*"Those who attain awakening **ascend to the celestial hall**."*

Again it says:
*"The foolish may become wise,
The turbid may become clear—
All by decree.
Foolishness is dim and murky,
Turbidity is dark and obscure—
Yet these are shaped by **inherited wind and soil**.
Heaven’s divine mechanisms
Make people unaware—
Thus it is called **natural**.
If one knows one’s unawareness,
It is also called **natural**.
The marvel of **naturalness**,
Though wondrous in knowing,
Its wonder lies in **unknowing**.
Yet in the Dao,
There was never **foolishness or turbidity**."*

Again it says:
*"All that I have proclaimed—
The worthy who receive the scripture
Must **dig for gold and place coins**,
**Swear to heaven** in its transmission."*

The disciples, this is the **true esoteric secret** of the *Jūshū Jīng*—the supreme, unfathomable treasure of serene liberation, the highest and most subtle of all. You merely recite the scriptures day and night, yet have never truly grasped their profound essence. If, while reciting and upholding them, you awaken to their hidden keys, then **sacred wisdom will be complete and luminous insight will arise**.

The **Ultimate Way** is profound and ineffable—neither visible nor audible. Had it not been for the **Celestial Worthy’s** opening of the serene mind and awakening of boundless aspiration **fifteen hundred kalpas** ago, seeking to deliver all beings and lead them to the peak of perfection—then declaring that the **source is emptiness**, with neither sound to hear nor form to see—if there is no sound to hear, then **forget the ears**; if there is no form to perceive, then **forget the eyes**. When ears and eyes are forgotten, then hearing and seeing will also vanish. Thus, ears and eyes, having form and color, are the leaders of the **six senses**; hearing and seeing, clinging to appearances and thoughts, are truly the **roots of the six senses**. How could they align with the **Dao**?

If one can purify the **six aspects** and sweep away the **six cognitions**, then the ears that do not listen **listen with the mind**, and the eyes that do not see **see with the spirit**. Thus, one does not listen yet hears, does not see yet sees. Without hearing or seeing, one is in accord with the **Dao**.

The *Chìwén Dònggǔ Jīng* says:
*"To forget the eyes, light overflows without limit;
To forget the ears, the mind’s depths remain ever still.
Both mechanisms forgotten, one enters the gate of all marvels.
Seeing without seeing me, hearing without hearing—
Detached from all boundaries, this is called the **Mystic Way**."*

The *Nánhuá Jīng* says:
*"Qi halts at the ears, the heart halts at the talisman."*

Thus, the *Jūshū Jīng* says:
*"To forget form and self is the mechanism of entering the **Dao**.
Again, with sincerity one enters—this ‘sincerity’ is **precept**.
With silence one guards—this ‘silence’ is **observing precepts to subdue body and mind**.
To use silence as if speechless is to enter **samādhi**, forgetting ears and eyes.
To act with gentleness as if clumsy is to conceal wisdom within the profound.
Again it says:
‘You seek within your own colored form to hear or see—
Yet it will never be visible or audible.’*

The *Vajra Sūtra* says:
*"If one seeks me through form or sound,
That person walks the crooked path and cannot see the Tathāgata."*

Now, those who seek the **Dao** must **receive precepts and enter samādhi**, secretly cultivating wisdom, confusing clarity with obscurity, yet not hearing while hearing, not seeing while seeing. Thus, those entering the **Dao** know **restraint**—this is the practice of **observing precepts and stilling thoughts**; know **caution**—this is the practice of **solitary vigilance and diligence**; know **subtlety**—this is the practice of **abandoning the sage and discarding wisdom**.

To still thoughts, one must **observe precepts**; to practice solitary vigilance, one must **enter samādhi**; to know subtlety, one must **cultivate wisdom**. If one truly **observes precepts, enters samādhi, and cultivates wisdom**, then body and mind will be perfectly tranquil, sacred wisdom complete, and luminous insight universally radiant. When the luminous insight penetrates, one merges with the **Dao**—this is called **true forgetting**. This **true forgetting** is not the **true forgetting** of sitting idle in empty meditation, but **true emptiness**. Within this **true emptiness**, there exists a **purple-golden wondrous form**—the marvel of **emptiness within non-emptiness**. If one does not fall into **coarse emptiness**, yet remains within **non-emptiness**, then the **subtle essence** naturally manifests. It is only because of **forgetting without forgetting what is forgotten** that one attains the **supreme and wondrous Way**.

Again it says:
*"Fools and sages differ—thus clarity and turbidity vary.
Though shaped by unequal **inherited wind and soil**,
All are mechanisms of **creation’s workings**,
Divine motion unfolding naturally,
The logic of **qi and fate**—already decreed by destiny.
Yet fools make themselves foolish, sages make themselves wise—
How could Heaven reward or punish their wisdom or folly?
Only by awakening a **serene mind** and establishing a **boundless aspiration**—
To depart the world and deliver others,
One must first hear the **Dao** and deliver oneself.
Those who deliver themselves **take refuge in the Three Jewels**,
Receive precepts, enter samādhi,
Cultivate wisdom to emit radiance—
Then fools may become wise, and the turbid may become clear.
If one cannot **observe precepts, enter samādhi**, or penetrate wisdom,
Without radiance to illuminate,
Then clarity may become turbid, and wisdom may become folly."*

The *Vajra Sūtra* says:
*"My teachings have no fixed form—
This is what is meant."*

The wisdom-light spoken of—**resplendent, vast, and profound**—illuminates the **dharma-realm**. How could it ever transcend the *Jūshū Bǎo Jīng*? **Jūshū** is the **true mechanism**. Those who wish to **turn the scripture** must first **turn the true mechanism**, secretly cultivating **merit and wisdom**. Yet I fear the **hidden light** cannot be opened or seen.

How could one **discern the forms of ghosts and spirits**, grasp the **pivot of creation**, participate in **Heaven and Earth’s transformation**, govern the **movement of sun and moon**, contain the **dharma-realm within a grain of millet**, and settle all things **before their origin**—to be called **Master of the Mystic Way**, advancing to the **Celestial Immortal’s realm**?

It is said:
*"Seeing the hidden light, one hears the **Dao’s root**.
Without cultivating **precepts and samādhi**, how could wisdom’s light be profound?
Clinging to appearances is not the true form—
Only by forgetting hearing can one truly hear.
Hearing, thinking, and cultivating enter the marvel—
The boundless ocean’s sound, free and at ease."*

**The Nineteen Marvels of Divine Powers**

Disciples, the wisdom-light of the **Dao** spoken of above—**the *Jūshū Jīng*** merely says that **hearing and seeing are extinguished**. Without hearing or seeing, the **marvels are already exhausted**, and **divine powers manifest**.

The *Yīnfú Jīng* says:
*"The deaf see, the blind hear."*

Ancient immortals say:
*"In stillness, no thunder is heard;
In deep gaze, no Mount Tài is seen."*

The *Zhōngyōng* says:
*"The virtue of ghosts and spirits—
How magnificent it is!
To see them, yet not see;
To hear them, yet not hear."*

*The Zhuangzi* says:
*"See nothing, hear nothing—
Embrace the Spirit and remain still."*

*The Parameters of the Mysterious* states:
*"The three treasures of ear, mouth, and eye—
Seal them shut, let nothing pass through.
The True Person dwells in the deep abyss,
Floating and guarding within the rule’s embrace."*

All the profound words in the scriptures cannot be exhausted.
The Great Compassionate One, Guanyin, through hearing, thinking, and cultivation,
Enters samādhi.

Now, the ear is the orifice for **leaking essence**—
Not the leakage of post-heaven’s superficial desires,
But the **pre-heavenal Ta Yi’s true qi**, the **manifested essence of the original vitality**.
If one internally listens and seals the hearing,
Then essence does not scatter, and wisdom arises.

The eye is the orifice for **leaking spirit**—
Not the leakage of post-heaven’s deliberative spirit,
But the **pre-heavenal subtle form of luminous awareness**, the **original spirit of the Great Primordial’s misty haze**.
If one internally gazes and returns the clarity,
Then it does not wander externally, and insight is born.

To uphold precepts and enter concentration—
Then wisdom arises.
Wisdom arises, and water and fire unite.
Water and fire unite, and **Kan and Li** are paired.
**Kan and Li** paired, and **Heaven and Earth** are harmonious.
**Heaven and Earth** harmonious, and **Metal and Wood** merge.
**Metal and Wood** merge, and **hun and po** reunite.
**Hun and po** reunite, and **essence and qi** transform.
**Essence and qi** transform, and **divine powers manifest**.
Divine powers manifest, and **light radiates**.
Light radiates, and **merit is complete**.
Merit complete, and the **Dharma-body is formed**.
The **Dharma-body formed**, and the **Dao-body is revealed**.
The **Dao-body revealed**, and **marvelous functions operate**.
Marvelous functions operate, and **sentient beings are liberated**.
Sentient beings liberated, and **vows are fulfilled**.
Vows fulfilled, and the **great matter is accomplished**.
The **great matter accomplished**, and **rank and fruit are attained**.

Only this **One Vehicle** is true—
The other two are not genuine.
From beginning to end, it does not depart from **sincerity**.
*The Zhongyong* says:
*"Without sincerity, there is nothing."*

**Things**—
Vague and indistinct, yet within them, there is substance;
Dark and obscure, yet within them, there is essence.
Their essence is most true, and within it, there is **faith**.
**Faith** is **sincerity**—
This is what the *Yijing* speaks of as **"qi and essence forming things"**, the **"material" of the *Great Learning***.
**Essence** is the **"one essence"** of the *Shangshu*.
**Middle** is the **"middle"** of **"its own middle"**.

*The Lotus Sutra* says:
*"There is a treasure hidden within the mountain of form,
Which the sages use to purify the heart and retreat into secrecy.
All are none other than this very thing—
First retreat, then reveal."*

An ancient song says:
*"If this heart holds nothing at all,
Before your eyes lies the moment of submission."*

What need for divine powers and marvelous functions?
What need for wisdom and light?
These divine powers and marvelous functions
Are the True Persons of the **Dao’s precepts** manifesting themselves
To liberate sentient beings, guiding delusion back to truth.

Thus, within the radiance of great wisdom,
The arm of compassion extends—
Rescuing all beings,
Freeing them from suffering into tranquility.
It grants longevity to those with short lives,
Transforming calamity into ease.
It brings peace to lands, extending life and preserving vitality.
It purifies sentient beings, making them virtuous and upright,
Banishing demons, driving away the strong and rebellious,
Exterminating malevolent spirits.
It makes sentient beings merciful and non-killing,
Causing them to preserve the **eon’s fate** and resolve grievances.
It shatters their darkness, revealing light.
It heals all diseases, dispelling ancient ailments.
It turns the foolish into the wise, leading them to the true and away from evil.
It makes them desireless and pure-hearted, gathering emotions back to nature.
It grants unobstructed liberation, transcending the mundane to become sage.
It accumulates merit and dispels calamity, bringing auspiciousness and eliminating sin.
It achieves transcendence and attains the **Dao**, escaping suffering to become immortal.
It enables cultivation of the **Highest Vehicle**, ascending to heaven,
Leading all sentient beings, wandering the eight extremes,
Surpassing celestial palaces.

May all sentient beings, in their ordinary forms,
Become **Dharma-kings**—
Even beyond measure, called **divine powers**.
Not revealing the secret in this age, called **marvelous functions**.

Thus, the divine powers of the **precepts, concentration, and wisdom** gate
Are the **non-divine divine**—
Transforming the six senses into the six **liberations**,
Communicating with heaven and earth,
With gods and ghosts,
With humans and things—
This is called **divine power**.

This **marvelous yet functional marvel**,
With one mechanism, demonstrates ten thousand transformations.
Transforming **heavenly demons**, **earthly coalas**, **ten thousand ghosts**, **evil beings**, **monsters**—
This is called **marvelous function**.

In the **precepts and concentration** gate, one enters stillness,
And light arises from **concentration and wisdom**—
The **pre-heavenal qi’s round and luminous auspicious form**.
Above, it communicates with the **Celestial Palace**, paying homage to the **Three Pure Ones**.
Below, it communicates with the **Underworld**, pardoning guilty spirits in the **Nine Abysses**.

When teaching, celestial deities submit,
The Five Emperors attend in solemnity,
Ten thousand spirits guard in orderly ranks,
Eager to hear the true **Dharma** and refine their spirits back to emptiness.
Having attained liberation, with compassion and pity,
They rescue the suffering, cold, and lost,
And the **Pure Assembly** praises, **Dìzhàng** shines forth,
Ghost judges obey, and the **Netherworld officials** submit,
Pardoning sins and granting rebirth,
Hearing the true **Dharma**, escaping the **Ghost Register**,
All ascending to **Extreme Bliss**.

Thus, self-liberation and liberation of others,
Taking great vows—
Wishing all sentient beings to universally hear the **Highest Way**,
Using the **Dharma-medicine** to universally save all beings,
Even the dull and moving with life,
All attain liberation.
Earth and wood, tiles and rubble—
All respond and communicate.
All things’ emotions are thoroughly penetrated.

Divine powers operate in **unaware unawareness**,
And heaven and earth, ten thousand things, are within my body.
Marvelous functions manifest in **natural spontaneity**,
And mountains, rivers, stars, and constellations return to the **Law**.

Heavenly demons all respectfully submit,
Bowing their heads in reverence.
Earthly coalas are all transformed into benevolence,
Their reverent hearts subdued.
Ferocious and cruel ghosts, upon hearing, ascend and forever abandon blood offerings.
Asuras and heterodox sects submit to the **Law** and return to correctness.

「War forever ceases, grievances are fully resolved, and grudges dissolve.
With **virtue/power** to transform, not with force to subdue,
Then wicked beings all become virtuous folk;
With **sincerity** to move, not with **craft** to ensnare,
Then errant souls all return to righteousness.

Inverting the **Fighting Star** to govern **yin-yang**,
Yet gods and spirits cannot fathom its marvel;
Upside-down wielding the **transformation-mechanism** beyond the world,
And heaven and earth remain unaware.

Universal manifestation of divine luminosity,
Firmly established in the **Law-body**,
Yet no form can be perceived.
Broadly proclaiming the supreme **vehicle** of one wondrous **Law**,
Yet no sound can be heard.

The **void** is my **Law-realm**,
I am the **Law-body** of the **void**.
Mingling indistinctly, I am one with heaven;
Upright and vast, I am one in heart with **Daoist immortals** and **Buddhas**.

Zhengzi said:
*"Expanding, it fills the six directions;
Contracting, it retreats and hides in secrecy."*
This is what he meant.

So-called parent of all beings,
**Daoist** master of the **Law**—
Is it not the **divine powers** of tranquil liberation,
The **wondrous functions** of **non-action** and natural spontaneity?

All children,
If you do not cling to forms,
Then your **wisdom** will be vast and boundless;
If you follow **heaven’s** natural course,
Then your **wondrous functions** will be infinite.

It is simply about
Diligently seeking the **Dao** in daily life without slacking,
And in haste without abandoning—
The two characters **"virtue/power"** and **"Way"** alone.

Why then forsake **precepts** and **disciplinary laws** to study **talismans** and **ritual arts**,
Or abandon **jade** and **precious gems** to cling to **coarse incantations**?
Would you rather be the foolish multitude,
Not learning the **supreme vehicle** of the **Way**?

Alas! All children entering the **mystic gate**,
Should seek the **supreme vehicle**.
Each person contains a **wondrous secret**,
Every individual is inherently luminous.

When **mindful attachments** arise, they bring many obstacles;
When **precepts** are held lightly, they become mere hollow words.
Even if **meditative focus** is strong,
If **resolve** is weak and **precepts** are not deeply held,
Then **divine powers** and **wondrous functions** remain elusive.

To attain **divine powers** and **wondrous functions**,
All children must rely on **sincere progress**.
If you foolishly cling to forms in pursuit,
Then a life in **ghostly caverns** will never lead to true **Way**.

Heterodox sects and external **Dao** schools often dwell in shapes,
Clinging to **emptiness** while dwelling in **color**—
This is not true cultivation.

Neither clinging to **emptiness** nor to **color**,
When **meditative focus** is deep and **sincere response** is thorough,
Then **divine powers** manifest naturally.

When **wondrous functions** are wielded,
The **divine luminosity** distinguishes itself—
Yet how many **Daoists** lose the **central function**!

I am not speaking at length for no reason—
Ah! I am revealing **heaven’s** true mechanism.

**Divine powers** manifest, **wondrous functions** shine forth,
The **Law-king** of boundless **Dao**—
Not departing from the **true constant** of tranquil stillness,
The **heretical teachings** submit in heart, and evil transforms into good.

Those who defy filial piety and fraternal duty,
Upon awakening, become instantly **benevolent and gentle**.
**Wisdom** is like a mirror,
**Illumination** like a **divine spirit**,
A single **luminous platform** blazing brightly.

The **Six Perfections** interweave without trace of dust,
And the earth, mountains, and rivers all become **gold**.

All children, do not neglect the **precepts** lightly held,
For they are the **heavenly ladder** by which you ascend step by step.

**Divine powers** are unfathomable,
**Wondrous functions** immeasurable—
Yet they never depart from **precepts** and **meditative focus**,
The **true constant** of **wondrous functions**.

The **gate** of **Thusness** has a **passage to heaven**,
Within the **non-dual fast**, **sacred fragrance** is exhaled.

All children, if you cultivate **sincerely** without self-abandonment,
Then the **ancient Daoist** and **Buddhist** **Great Assembly Hall** is yours.

Twenty years of enlightenment into **birth-and-death**—
All children, from ancient times to now,
The **sages**, **immortals**, **Buddhas**, and **patriarchs**,
Only for the sake of great **causes and conditions**,
Nine years facing the wall,
Seeking urgently to penetrate **birth-and-death**,
To subdue the **heart of worldly existence**.

Have you not heard?
**Stone-fire**, **lightning-flash**, **falling flowers**, **fleeting water**—
When **impermanence** arrives,
Not even a moment can be retained.
**Karma** follows the body,
And **rebirth** brings retribution.

Words not yet finished, yet the breath in the throat is severed,
Speech not yet uttered, yet the tongue shrinks and cannot sound.
Naked and stripped, where shall you rest your body?
Dark and boundless, who shall stand firm in your fate?

Great **blessings** lead to rebirth in the world,
Evil **deeds** plunge you into **Fengdu**’s depths.
When **blessings** are exhausted, you return to **rebirth**,
And when **karma** is complete, you transform into **beasts**.

For **aeons** you are ensnared by **grudges**,
Unable to escape;
For **thousands of lives**, **guilt** cannot be erased.

World after world, you sink in **delusion**,
Drunken in **life**, dead in **dreams**.
**Grudges** beget **grudges**,
And you wear **horns** and **fur** as retribution.

To speak of it is painful and pitiful,
To recount it is sorrowful and terrifying.

If you do not **fix your resolve** and **establish your intention**,
Grasping firmly your **innate moral nature**—
Uncovering the earth, overturning the heavens,
Awakening to how **death** truly unfolds;
Surrendering your **heart**, relinquishing your **life**,
Piercing the **ignorance** of your **past lives**—

If you encounter a **resolute warrior**,
Who raises his brows straight,
And wields the **treasured sword** to cut **demons**—
Truly a **great man**,
Who releases his **great qi**,
And severs **heresy** with a **sharp blade** in his heart.

Ultimately, you must see through:
Before your **parents** gave birth to you,
Where did you establish your **command**?
And after **death** claims you,
Where shall you rest your **body**?

Awakening to the **Three Bodies**—
Past, future, and present—
Pursuing exhaustively the **Three Worlds**,
As if they were yesterday;
The **coming morning** is this very dawn.

Thus, all **thoughts** are dispelled,
Only this **luminous light** remains.
All **conditions** are swept clean,
Only that **illuminated nature** endures.

Entering the **mystic gate**,
One **passage** opens, and all **passages** open;
Seeing the **true teaching**,
Then the **Three Realms** are clear, and the **Three Worlds** depart.

Liberation means the **Five Elements** do not cling,
And **void** stillness means the **Four Great Elements** return to **emptiness**.

Entering the **gate of myriad wonders**,
Ascending to the **ground of the Three Jewels**,
Coming and going freely,
Transformation without bounds—

Lightly turning **heaven’s** mechanism,
Then **ghosts** and **spirits** cannot measure its **marvel**.
Majestically reversing the **Fighting Star**,
Then **yin-yang** cannot control its **authority**.

Soaring in the **Vimalakirti’s** **subtle essence**,
Attaining the **position** of **void** and **boundless** stillness—
Forever departing from **dusty kalpas**,
Escaping the **cage of existence**.

The **Great Matter** of **Perfect Truth** is accomplished,
Layer by layer, the **great path** is traversed,
Without practicing **discrimination** yet arriving swiftly.

This **wondrous Law-body** of **Dao**,
All its **secrets** are obtained from **illumination**—
Step by step, **hidden techniques** are perfected,
How could one not awaken and achieve **harmony**?

All children!
The **Way** lies in **sacred transmission**,
Cultivation lies in **yourself**—」

The **virtue/power** comes from human accumulation,
The mirror comes from **Heaven**.

Further, one does not hear of **Heaven** dividing its **creative transformation** within the One,
Nor of humans establishing **dharma** and **precepts** from the heart.

Each person must strive swiftly to uphold and practice,
Urging themselves to press forward without delay.

Those yet **unawakened** shall not lose the **auspicious cause**,
Those who **pierce through** shall return to the **Celestial Realm**,
While the **unawakened** shall not fall into the **hells**.
All children!

Even if you knock with a **golden brick** at the gate,
The gate shall not open,
Yet the **golden brick** remains.

To uphold **precepts** and cultivate the **Dao** though still **unawakened**,
If the **precepts** persist,
You shall not sink into the **Netherworld**,
Ultimately reborn in the **yang** world.

If the **past causes** are not obscured,
The **fruit of realization** shall naturally manifest—
Just a slight turn,
And you still hold the **handle** in hand.

All children!
Do not seek **birth-and-death** outside yourself.
When **birth-and-death** is realized,
Only then do you know the **true essence** within the heart.

I have spoken at length now,
Yet it amounts to no **method**.
If you **embody** the heart in this way,
You shall yourself find that **principle**.

**Death** is examined in **life**,
**Life** is realized in **death**—
This **mechanism** of **life-and-death**,
The **pathway** lies in human **transformation**,
By your will, not mine.

To seek **stillness** within **movement**,
To find **movement** within **stillness**,
Then the **essence** of **movement-and-stillness**,
All depends on the **true knowing** within.

You may question the **heart**,
But you cannot question the **Teacher**.
Heed my words carefully,
And you shall never go astray.
If you do not follow my words,
You shall inevitably lag behind.

The dim lamp of my path
Guides countless lost travelers through the dark.

This raft of suffering
Ferries guests across the endless ocean of the Ganges.

Disciples, do not harbor doubt—
When you recognize the truth, walk swiftly by night.

Then, in the silent hall, voices rise in praise:
*"Where was home before birth?*
*Where shall we return after death?*
*Now, awaken to the Dharma-body,*
*Lest you pass your prime with empty hands.*

*Life and death intertwine—*
*This great matter of cause and effect is no trifle.*
*Before death, first embody its likeness,*
*For the breath of life lies hidden in death.*

*Not in water, not in mountain,*
*Why seek west or east or south or north?*
*Look not beyond your own body—*
*Truth dwells within this narrow span.*

*With precept, concentration, and wisdom,*
*Enter the Mystic Pass,*
*Lest your practice falter in the second or third step.*
*With single mind, comprehend life and death,*
*And iron walls and bronze fortresses shall crumble with ease.*

*True suffering—oh, how arduous!*
*Yet like a boat gliding over shallow waters.*
*Suddenly, the tide turns fair,*
*The wind aligns—*
*In an instant, you sail past the Nine Dragon Bay.*

*When you recognize the truth,*
*Walk by night without hesitation,*
*And all props dissolve into none.*

*Empty, boundless, solitary in practice,*
*Neither thirst nor hunger—*
*Eternal as heaven and earth.*

*The twenty-one virtues perfected,*
*Disciples!*

The boundless void—here lies the ladder to heaven within the gates of precept and concentration.
The boundless sea of suffering—here lies the vessel to cross within the radiance of wisdom.

If you do not stride forward with open steps,
The ninety-thousand *li* of the path shall never be reached.
If you do not straighten your spine and press on,
The true Dharma shall not be heard across a thousand kalpas.

Should your steps falter and your resolve weaken,
How shall your virtue be perfected, your power fulfilled?

Disciples, let no thread of thought leak from your mind—
Let your primordial *qi* naturally fill, harmonize, and suffuse.

To subdue spirits and gods through virtue,
Only then may you escape the retribution of rebirth.
To align with the Dao of heaven and earth,
Only then may you transcend the path of life and death.

Ascend to the Dao’s shore—
Turn and you stand in your homeland.
Plunge into the Mystic Depths—
Blink, and you return to your original form.

Disciples!
Who harbors immortality?
Who beholds eternal life?
The undying is not this mortal frame;
The ever-living is not mere form and substance.

Where is Pengzu now?
Where does Yanzi endure across kalpas?
The undying is my Dharma-body;
The ever-living is my primordial *qi*.

Even the Tathagata has a time of quiescence,
Deep in the realm of *nirvana*;
Even Laozi had his day of ascension,
Soaring to the Great Red Sky.

The Dao abides—so does the person.
The Law abides—so does the self.
To die without forgetting is longevity—
A nameless name unbroken across countless kalpas.
To live without possession is form—
A formless form unharmed through ages.

Countless as the sands of the Ganges,
No sage escapes this Mystic Pass.
Numberless as the void,
No immortal or Buddha bypasses this Great Way.

The clear path of heaven is plain—
Yet how can it save those lost in doubt?
The serene Buddha-land is pure—
Yet how can it free the common folk from their shackles?

Only those with shallow fortune and deep sin,
Though they see, are blind as the sightless.
Many bear heavy karmic burdens,
Though alive, are already dead.

Flesh moves, corpse walks—
No better than beasts, save for speech and wit.
Day sleeps, night dreams—
Worse than plants, lacking even upright growth.

When your time is due, ghosts shall drag you—
No mercy for the "Perfect Truth" adept.
Not a word amiss in judgment—
You are still deemed a wicked, virtue-less man.

Disciples,
All must die—yet let it be well.
Pure, clean, unencumbered,
Coming and going with ease, without restraint.

All must disperse—yet let it be wondrous.
Clear, unbound, effortless,
Transformation complete yet unfathomable.

Before departing, bow to all.
The hour has come—release your grip and go.

Bare as a newborn, radiant *qi* blazes from the crown—
A thousand auspicious lights.
Round and luminous, ascending in marvelous form—
Halfway to heaven, white cranes soar on clouds.

Many celestial scenes—
The spirit returns to the void.
One auspicious glow—
The true bones rest in the cavern.

The great man’s deeds are complete!
Leave behind a name among mortals,
Pass down a teaching to the world,
So that in countless ages,
Some may know of you.

This is to die yet not perish—*shou*.
To propagate the Dao across eons—
This is the body of perfect fulfillment,
Perfect virtue, perfect fortune.

Disciples,
Life and death rest with you alone—
No one can save you.
If you do not cultivate yourself,
No one can do it for you.
Thoughts arise and vanish—
You cannot always grasp them.
Delusion and selfishness—
You cannot always purge them.
Deep attachments—
You cannot always abandon them.
The Dharma-body without form—
You cannot always recognize it.
Precepts and rules—
You cannot always uphold them.
Afflictions and ignorance—
You cannot always extinguish them.
Worldly habits—
You cannot always dissolve them.
Obstacles—
You cannot always remove them.
Sacred mantras and wondrous methods—
You cannot always follow them.
Karma of merit and sin—
You cannot always believe in them.
Worldly mind and attitudes—
You cannot always forget them.
Desires and clinging—
You cannot always empty them.
False paths and heterodoxies—
You cannot always discern them.
Transient illusions—
You cannot always penetrate them.
All things—
You cannot always respond to them.
Realms and stages—
You cannot always transcend them.
Sages and true teachers—
You cannot always seek them.
The boundless Dao—
You cannot always enter it.
This very life—
You cannot always save it.
Your original aspiration—
You cannot fully realize it.

Disciples, why is this?
Because of your arrogance and pride,
I cannot transform you.
With gentle words, I cannot persuade you.
With doubt, I cannot awaken you.
With heavy sins, I cannot redeem you.
With rage and slander, I cannot restrain you.
With flattery, I cannot defy you.
With stubbornness, I cannot guide you.
With deceit, I cannot abandon you.
With honest words, you cannot accept them.
With delusion, I cannot break through.
With blindness, I cannot enlighten.
With recklessness, I cannot restrain.
With sickness and suffering, I cannot heal.
With fate and calamity, I cannot spare.
With predestined time, I cannot pardon.
With karmic retribution, I cannot free.
With cosmic law, I cannot exempt.
With fiery mountains and sword-trees, I cannot shield.
With the boat of compassion, I cannot ferry.
With elixirs and treasures, I cannot bestow.
Though heaven’s secrets may turn you,
Though divine powers may guide you—
Disciples, only through resolute aspiration and strict observance,
Without deviation in precepts,
Seeking singularity in concentration,
With sincerity undivided—
Only then do you truly turn back to the Way.

Disciples, turn back to the Way,
And repentance shall naturally cleanse you.

**Translation:**

To take refuge in the Great Dao,
All entanglements may be severed.

The celestial mysteries of the Pure Void,
May be approached through natural clarity.

The darkness of the Underworld,
May be dispelled by natural light.

Great calamities and vast disasters,
May be escaped through the wheel of rebirth.

The impermanence of life and death,
May be grasped with firm resolve.

The boundless Dao,
May be naturally aligned with heart to heart.

The peerless Dharma-body,
May be realized with perfect clarity.

Limitless blessings,
May be received with natural stability.

Infinite beings,
May be saved one by one.

Vast vows and profound aspirations,
May be fulfilled with natural depth.

As the earth endures and heaven lasts,
Longevity may be shared with natural measure.

Only with a clear mind,
May all obstructions be naturally penetrated.

Only with sincerity,
May even gold and stone be pierced.

Only with emptiness,
May not even a speck be stained.

Only with constancy,
May demons be unable to seize.

Only with kindness,
May grudges and malevolence be naturally transformed.

Only with true intent,
May demonic forces dare not provoke.

Only with clarity,
May sages be attained—
Naturally enlightened.

Only with awakened mind,
May immortals and Buddhas be realized—
Naturally perfected.

Only with emptiness,
May profound principles be seen—
Naturally penetrated.

Only with purity,
May wondrous forms be recognized—
Naturally enlightened.

Only with illumination,
May true emptiness be attained—
Naturally in accord.

Only with steadfastness,
May life and death be understood—
Naturally free from guilt.

Only with impartiality,
May spirits and gods be addressed—
Naturally without deception.

Only with rectitude,
May demons be subdued—
Naturally radiant.

Only with sincerity,
May evil forces be subdued—
Naturally wise.

Only with generosity,
May divine beings be approached—
Naturally potent in aspiration.

Only with compassion,
May the dull and stubborn be transformed—
Naturally sheltered.

Only with awe-inspiring resolve,
May the cruel and wicked be subdued—
Naturally fearless.

Only with patience,
May nothing be abandoned—
Naturally magnanimous.

Only with emptiness,
May formlessness be retained—
Naturally awakened and illuminated.

Only with forgetfulness,
May formlessness be discerned—
Naturally free from self and others.

Only with maternal heart,
May all beings be known—
Selflessly saving all.

Only with no-mind,
May any realm be dwelled in—
Naturally complete and free.

Only with perfect penetration,
May the Three Realms be unbound—
Naturally without obstruction.

Only with a heart of benefit,
May no eon be uncrossed.

Only with a tranquil mind,
May the boundless be inhabited—
Naturally perfect and complete.

Disciples, my teaching is now complete,
The Dao-field is fulfilled.

Yet I ponder you—
Father and son ascending the mountain,
A father cannot pass the Dao to his son,
Nor can a son replace his father.
Each follows the Way alone,
Knowing cold and warmth for oneself,
Advancing or retreating by one’s own will.

Thus, my teaching holds no single method.
Only like prescribing medicine to cure illness,
Administering remedies to symptoms.
When the ailment is healed and the symptoms vanish,
No further need for prescriptions or medicine remains.

Like crossing a river—
A boat is necessary until the shore is reached.
Once ashore, one does not cling to the boat.

Like threading a needle—
Once the garment is sewn, no further need for needle or thread.

Do not add unnecessary embellishments,
Or seek the snake after the grass is pulled.

Only strive earnestly forward,
Upholding precepts with sincerity and discipline.
Within precepts, forget precepts;
Beyond laws, add laws.
When the practice is profound and the moment arrives,
You shall naturally be raised by the ancestors,
Guided to true enlightenment.

Do not lack resolve,
Relying on teachers or leaning on fellow practitioners,
Clinging to names and forms,
All day and year,
Blindly following others’ footsteps.

Instead, fix your heart,
Unshaken by doubt.
With single-minded devotion,
Unwavering even unto death.

When the moment is ripe,
Has not Heaven never failed the resolute?

The Dao stands still and unmoving,
Yet those who respond may attain it.

Disciples, if you truly cultivate fierce intent,
Pressing forward without hesitation,
Yearning without turning back—
This is high aspiration,
The seed of the Dao’s gate.

The Master’s silent verse,
Not lightly revealed to all,
Now I recite for you—
Listen closely.

**"The Verse Says:**

Life and death are transient—awaken to this truth,
Die alone, unconcerned by others’ eyes.

Do not lean on others for your own salvation,
Even gods and immortals must cross the river alone.

Not just the six dusts and six senses,
Nor clinging to any single path—
The mind must dwell ever-present,
Yet neither cling to permanence nor to impermanence.

Knowing the cause, you pierce through illusion’s veil—
No cause remains when wisdom dawns.

On the path of origin, you perceive the emptiness of self-nature,
At fruition, you awaken—who then abides in that void?

From this day forth, sever life and death’s snare,
Erase the ledger of rebirth’s wheel.

If one follows the law with strict observance,
Heaven’s unseen spirits will mark it well.

The Dragon Gate’s teaching is without foundation—
Harsh words reveal its single truth.

Do not cling to the law’s letter, sweep it aside,
Only then will the verse’s essence shine clear.

Study my words until the Dharma-body is known—
The void itself is the boundless treasure-house.

Move, and thought arises without end,
The Dao’s storehouse within the body extends blessings.

The teaching merges with the mind, mind is the teaching—
No end to the long pole’s reach.

**—*Scripture of the Azure Grove, Final Volume*"**

「The Twenty-Second Insight into the Primordial Source:
All disciples, this single point of unobscured void and spirit—
Is it not easily seen? Who then is this Primordial Source, the True Person of my Essence?

From ancient times to now, sages, immortals, Buddhas, and ancestral masters of the Dao,
Sat facing walls for nine years,
Or meditated in circles for six seasons,
Counting three threes and seven sevens,
Toiling and striving in earnest pursuit.

They traversed famous mountains and wandered blessed lands,
Sought teachers and questioned friends,
Inquired about the Way and listened to scriptures,
Practiced austere deeds and accumulated virtue through almsgiving.

All manner of cultivation—
Yet only to grasp this body’s life and death, its great karmic cause,
Unknown whence it came, unknown whither it goes,
Lost in wandering, sinking in rebirth,
Unable to escape the Wheel of Existence—
Thus they vow and strive in practice.

Some seek to sever thought and forget emotion,
As the path to transcendence,
And sit in meditation for three or five years,
Breaking countless *zazen* mats—
Yet how often has thought truly ceased,
Or emotion been forgotten?
This is but the five returning to the ten.

Some use *tianlian* (cooking lead) and *lianggong* (refining mercury)
As the path to transcendence,
And perform morning and evening rituals—
Retiring talismans, adding flames—
Yet how often have they seen the seven returns of the Jade Elixir,
Or the nine returns of the Golden Elixir?
How often have they caught the thief,
Only to release the thief again?

Some meditate on the Supreme Sovereign in silent devotion for three days.
Some refine and liberate to aid the lost,
Rescuing wandering souls from the Nine Realms of the Underworld;
Some call upon deities and summon generals,
Wearing talismans to command the True Persons;
Some raise *qi* and open the gates,
Circulating vital essence to proclaim the Wondrous Dao;
Some recite scriptures and toil in worship;
Some prepare elixirs to heal sickness and mend wounds;
Some refine and consume alchemical substances,
Hoping to ascend to the heavens;
Some imitate the *yin-yang* arts in gathering and taking;
Some breathe within the *dingqi* vessel,
Using divine *qi* to transmute lead and prolong life and command;
Some tend the sand-fire in the furnace,
Refining *maogen* (hemp roots),
Establishing merit through almsgiving.

Some cling to bodily suffering,
Embracing the *jin dan* (golden elixir) path,
Waiting for transmission to those of fortune.

Some, with shallow karmic roots,
Practice the most difficult of deeds,
Yet abandon them at the cliff’s edge.

All these obscure the true nature,
Engage in illusory cultivation—
They are but side paths.

All disciples,
To sever thought and forget emotion,
You must first perceive where thought arises,
Where emotion originates,
To grasp it firmly,
To press it steadily,
To recognize it truly,
To point it out clearly—
Only then may you proceed to sever,
Only then may you proceed to forget.

Now I ask you:
Who is this one who knows how to grasp,
How to seize,
How to recognize,
How to point out,
How to sever thought,
How to forget emotion?

Even if you sever thought and forget emotion,
Break countless meditation mats—
Thought remains thought,
Emotion remains emotion.

The assembly,
Severing thought as thought,
Is called *putting one’s head on top of one’s head*;
Forgetting emotion as emotion,
Is called *catching the thief and releasing the thief*.

Better yet,
To forget the very law of forgetting,
To sever the very law of severing—
Both roots forgotten,
Entering the Gate of Marvels—
This alone is the supreme teaching.

All disciples,
When I sever thought from the law,
You do not know that the law itself is the thought’s origin;
When I sever emotion from the law,
You do not know that the law itself is the seed of emotion.

The assembly,
Severing thought is not as good as thought severing itself,
Forgetting emotion is not as good as emotion forgetting itself—
This is called *seeking others is not as good as seeking oneself*.

All disciples,
Those who transmute lead and refine mercury,
Who adjust the fire’s stages,
Who mimic the *yin-yang* hexagrams—
They mutilate the *Taiqi* (Great Polarity) and *Hunyuan* (Chaos Primordial),
Taking false names as true practice,
Pointing at metaphors as actual deeds.

They rashly speak of the Three Fields,
Blindly guess at vital *qi* and essence,
The seven emotions as mechanical traps,
The nine orifices as pivotal hinges.

They take the seven characters and nine characters,
The returns and exchanges,
As seven times, nine times,
Seven rounds, nine rounds,
Seven stages, nine stages,
Seven years, nine years,
Seven transformations, nine transformations.

This drawing of diagrams,
That summoning of forms—
Today it is *Kan* and *Li* (Water and Fire) interacting,
Tomorrow it is *Earth-Heaven* (Tai) harmony,
The day after it is *Hun* and *Po* (soul and spirit) merging,
This year it is the same infant,
Next year it is the same infant—
Until nine years pass,
Still an ignorant, unborn sinner.

They do not know their own errors,
Yet shake their heads,
Curse their fingers,
And face outsiders with false claims:
*"On that day, I conceived the holy child,
The fire’s stages were nurtured correctly,
The bathing time was not amiss—
Yet why, after ten months, does no infant appear?
Is it because our fate is shallow, our sins deep,
And the spirits do not allow fulfillment?"*

They clutch their bellies,
Age their faces,
Strain their eyes,
And shed hollow tears.

Do you know these base-rooted, foolish ones?
They do not recognize their own heart,
Nor understand their true nature—
Their karma is thick as night,
What wisdom could they possess?
Do you know these people?
They still aspire upward,
Yet remain in darkness,
Unawakened to the path of ascent.

Your body’s essence and *qi*,
Are the Primordial *Yuanqi* (Original *Qi*) and *Yuanjing* (Original Essence)—
Unincreasing, undiminishing treasures.
If you stir them,
They do not grow;
If you do not stir them,
They do not wane.

This unobscured void and spirit—
The true essence—
Is the Primordial Spirit.

Yet they say,
*"What is this Primordial Spirit?
Is it not that infant?"*

From countless eons past,
Your sins remain unexpiated,
Obstacles unsevered,
The heart’s source uncleaned,
The nature’s root unilluminated.

You do not early repent your transgressions,
Nor change your disposition,
Nor seek a teacher to awaken to the Way—
Instead, you waste this precious, limited time,
Chasing that shadowy infant,
For what purpose?

All disciples,

Within your own bodies,
You know good and evil,
You know right and wrong,
You know corruption and rectitude,
You know birth and death,
You know self and other,
You know true and false—
This is the infant.

Yet this infant,
Originally does not know
Good and evil, right and wrong,
Corruption and rectitude, birth and death,
Self and other, true and false.

This infant does not cling to forms,
Nor does it generate mind from phenomena,
Nor mind from wisdom,
Nor wisdom from knowledge,
Nor knowledge from good to know evil,
Nor right to know wrong,
Nor rectitude to know corruption,
Nor birth to know death,
Nor self to know other,
Nor truth to know falsehood.

Originally devoid of *wōxiàng* (self-form),
And devoid of *fēikōngxiàng* (non-empty form),
It merely responds to all things
Through this point of perception in the world’s movement.

If one speaks of *Tàijí* (Supreme Polarity) and *Hùnyuán* (Chaotic Unity),
Then even this knowledge may be considered as *wúzhī* (non-knowledge).

Yet this knowledge is *liángzhī* (True Knowing),
The Buddhist school calls it *shànzhīshì* (Wise Knowing),
The Daoist school names it the *bāoyǐngyuánshén* (Infant Primordial Spirit).

In summary, all disciples,
It is merely this unobscured void-spirit essence—
The true nature of your being.

You only see Daoists enter the *yúnquán* (circular meditation chamber),
Practice sitting in meditation,
Speak of nurturing the embryo (*huáitāi*),
After ten months in seclusion,
Have you ever seen any Daoist
Reveal the infant’s form,
Manifest its luminosity?

Before they enter the *yúnquán*,
They do not know
The states of Heaven, Earth, ghosts, and gods,
The principles of *yīnyáng* (yin-yang),
The calamities and blessings of humankind,
The auspicious or inauspicious in the future,
Nor their year of birth or day of death.

After they leave the *yúnquán*,
They still do not know.

If they do not understand their own birth and death,
They cannot save themselves—
How can they save others?

If they do not comprehend their own birth and death,
Nor discern auspicious and inauspicious,
Bound by Heaven and Earth as they are,
Their birth is no different from the common folk’s sufferings,
Their death is no different from the ordinary’s fate—
Buried in filth, decaying in stench.

Then this entering the *yúnquán* to sit in meditation,
Is it not merely futile?

All disciples,
You must first forget the mind of death,
Then enter the *yúnquán*;
You must first sever the ties of desire,
Then practice sitting in meditation.

When lustful thoughts are long extinguished,
The kidneys suffice,
And true *lián* (lead) ascends.

When angry thoughts are long extinguished,
The heart becomes void,
And true *gōng* (mercury) descends.

When diet is regulated in accordance with the seasons,
The spleen grows strong,
And mercury and lead are sealed and fixed.

When emotions are emptied,
The lungs are moistened,
And when the nature is settled,
The liver flourishes,
And the kidneys’ waters abound—
Then the eyes shine brightly,
And the pupils are like black lacquer.

When the heart’s fire is quenched,
The mouth’s saliva fills,
And its taste is as sweet as *lì* (fermented rice drink).

When the spirit is pure,
The liver’s *qi* flows smoothly,
And the sinews and bones grow light.

When the ethereal soul is at peace,
The lungs’ fluids circulate,
And the hair and beard turn dark.

When the spleen is robust and the stomach harmonious,
The tongue and throat are agile,
And the voice resounds clear.

When the orifices are open and the blood is abundant,
All diseases are repelled;
When the five flavors are bland,
True *qi* arises.

By practicing *tāoyǐn* (guiding and pulling exercises)
In accordance with the four seasons and eight periods,
You can resist the intrusion of wind, cold, heat, and dampness.

By restraining the six desires and seven emotions,
And subduing the nature to calm the mind,
You can ward off the influence of demons and malevolent spirits.

By seeking the Great Dao,
True Knowing manifests,
And the true nature is illuminated.

When you awaken to *zhēnrú* (Suchness),
The physical form becomes void,
And the Dharma-body is revealed.

First save yourself,
Then save others—
But ultimately, it is to save yourself.

All disciples,
At this stage,
You have only taken the first step
Through the great gate.

Then, enter the *yúnquán* to sit in stillness,
Ascend to Heaven,
Descend to Earth,
And perceive the states of ghosts and gods,
The mechanisms of Heaven and Earth—
All within the breath’s span,
All within the grasp of creation.

This is all achieved through *jièdìng* (restraint and meditation).

Thus, when entering the *yúnquán*,
You are but a mortal embryo and ordinary bones;
When leaving the *yúnquán*,
You are a sacred body and Dharma-form.

Understanding the Great Dao,
Your vision expands—
You see through all ties as illusory and false.

With a staff in hand,
Your heart broadens—
You embrace Heaven and Earth within the boundless void.

Before others act, I already know;
Before events unfold, I foresee.

Only then is it the *liùtōng* (Six Perfections),
With boundless wisdom—
All heavenly demons bow in submission,
And the Dark Protectors (*àn hù*) reverently guard.

All external paths of the ten directions submit,
And all tremble in awe.

Within a sesame seed,
The *xūmíshān* (Sumeru Mountain) is contained—
Unperceived.

Within a grain of millet,
The ten-directional worlds are hidden—
Unknown.

At will, you roam
The vast Earth and mountains and rivers—
Unfettered.

At will, you retreat
Into the subtlest dust or grain—
Secure.

All disciples,
This Dao of effortless ascent to the utmost truth is first
In discerning the subtle principles and awakening to Heaven’s mysteries.

Thus, you must abandon
All blind meditation, chaotic sitting,
Cooking lead and refining mercury,
Concentrating on thoughts and visualizations,
Purifying and transforming to aid the lost,
Seeking official titles and records,
Shaking fans to gather *qi*,
Reciting sutras and chanting scriptures,
Mixing medicines and burning incense,
And all other practices of alchemical furnaces—
These myriad futile affairs,
Do not hasten to them,
But set them aside entirely.

Sincerely and earnestly,
Make vows to Heaven,
Swear with resolve.

From this day onward,
And into the future,
May you swiftly comprehend
The mysteries of birth and death,
Escape the suffering of cyclic existence,
Avoid all false paths,
And attain the wondrous Dao.

Ah!
This saying of *"avoiding all false paths"* (*lí zhǒngzhǒng biān*)
Is indeed the great expedient gate
For discerning the subtle principles and awakening to Heaven’s mysteries.

All disciples,
What are these *"false paths"*?

They are blind meditation, chaotic sitting,
Cooking lead and refining mercury—
All these peripheral practices.

What is *"false"*?
Peripheral practices are neither central nor correct.
Like a table’s edges,
These peripheral paths lie at the four sides—
They cannot enter the heart.
Even if they enter the heart,
They do not leave the table.
Yet you do not realize:
Only by leaving the table
Can one attain the void’s Great Dao.
If you cannot leave the table,
You remain but an object—
Not the Dao—
Is this not *"false"*?

*"False"* means seeking (*xún*),
It means deviation (*xié*),
It means boundary (*jiè*),
It means shore (*yá*).

Peripheral means not central,
Deviation means not upright.
With boundaries,
You cannot be vast and boundless;
With shores,
You cannot be profound and pure.

Clinging tightly to this fleshly sack,
mistaking it for a thousand-year-old cypress,
a ten-thousand-year-old green pine—
only to suffocate the true protagonist alive.

Instead, you abandon the lamp to seek fire,
cling to the false while discarding the true—
is this not tipping to one side?

Even if you succeed,
you remain but a *self-liberated one*.

You have not yet seen your true nature—
though you attain fruition,
your merits exhausted, you still enter the wheel of rebirth,
struggling to transcend the Three Realms.
What benefit do you bring to these beings?

Disciples,
to become an immortal, a Buddha,
a sage, or a worthy—
all lies in abandoning self for others,
in vowing to liberate all beings.

Now, these practitioners who sit in meditation
cannot even liberate themselves—
how could they liberate others?
Called *self-liberated ones*,
have they ever truly understood the Great Dao,
the boundless liberation of all?

They linger in peripheral practices—
deeply pitiable!

The True Lord speaks in verse,
revealing the true mechanism,
teaching the assembly to abandon self-seeking
and to step beyond one-sided methods.

Thus, those of peripheral teachings
return to the central path,
while deviant doctrines revert to the true law.
Bounded realms are opened into boundlessness,
the vast world unfolds to reach heaven and earth,
channeled ditches with shores are widened into limitless expanse.
The unfathomable Dharma-body
expands into formlessness, beyond self and other.

The scriptures say:
*"Seeing without seeing me,
hearing without hearing me,
leaving all boundaries—
this is called the wondrous Dao."*

Disciples,
the gate to realization begins with an open mind.
From where does life arise?
To where does death return?
Seek the lofty, enlightened teachers,
the wise and sincere friends.
Nurture boundless compassion,
and investigate thoroughly.

Life is like a cup of tea—
constrained by form, the water retains its taste.
Pour it into the Eastern Ocean,
and it becomes vast waves and surging tides.
If you seek my original source,
saying the water is now tea because of added flavor—
then it has color and form.
Yet within this ocean’s depths,
my original source resides.
What, then, is my original source?
Investigate carefully,
until seeing without sight,
hearing without sound.

With prolonged cultivation,
the chest suddenly opens,
the vision clears to the ground—
the original face is seen,
the subtle mechanism revealed,
and the true nature confirmed:
the Dao was never unworthy of humanity!

Disciples,
the sages, immortals, and Buddhas have long ascended.
To see their hearts,
first clarify their principles.
Clarifying their principles,
you awaken to their methods,
and act in their deeds.
Acting in their deeds,
you become their embodiment.

Disciples,
where is the heart of the sages, immortals, and Buddhas?
It lies within each person’s *fangcun* [heart-mind].
Where is their principle?
It stands before each person’s eyes.
Where is their method?
It is within the scriptures and histories.
Their deeds do not exceed worldly law—
they are found within worldly affairs.
Their bodies reside in their very core.

If you know the sages’, immortals’, and Buddhas’ hearts
within your *fangcun*,
you can clarify their principles.
Clarifying their principles,
you awaken to their methods.
Awakening to their methods,
you can act in their deeds.
Clarifying their principles,
the true path is preserved.
Awakening to their methods,
all conditions are realized.
Acting in their deeds,
meritorious deeds are established—
and the celestial mechanism never ceases,
enduring through countless kalpas.

Know that such a person’s supernatural powers and wisdom
already embody the sages’, immortals’, and Buddhas’ essence—
this is their heart.

Then, receiving the *Zhongji* Precepts,
the nature is opened,
the Mystic Pass unblocked—
and you can clarify their principles.
Then, receiving the *Tianxian* Precepts,
delving into profound truths,
wisdom becomes boundless—
and you can traverse their Dao.

Then, liberated without obstruction,
round or square,
vast or small,
moving or still,
forward or backward,
alive or dead,
bent or stretched,
exiting or entering,
sage or worthy,
immortal or Buddha—
you can manifest in the Four Births,
the Six Realms,
heaven or emptiness,
or the underworld.
Adapting teachings to each,
you liberate beings through kalpas.
Transformation is unfathomable,
manifesting in person to teach.

Like a boundless mirror reflecting all forms,
mutually containing—
you can act in their deeds,
become their embodiment,
and attain their fruition.

Disciples,
this is called *parametrizing subtle principles*
and *awakening to celestial mechanisms*.

Long ago, the Yellow Emperor lost his *Xuanzhu* [Mysterious Pearl]
in the Red River,
and sent *Lizhu* to retrieve it—
but *Lizhu* could not find it.
Then he sent *Qie Gou*—
*Qie Gou* could not find it.
Finally, he sent *Wangxiang*—
and *Wangxiang* obtained it.

*Lizhu* was one who dwelled in the *Ligong* [Red Palace],
the post-heavenal fleshly cluster of the heart—
thus he could not find it,
symbolizing those today who cling to one-sided views.

*Qie Gou* was one who clung to defilements,
practicing purity of mouth and body,
relying on fasting—
yet even this refined heart could not attain it.

As for *Wangxiang*,
how did he succeed?

The *Wángxiàng*—*wáng* means "none," *xiàng* means "form and color."
Thus, *Wángxiàng* refers to that which is formless and colorless.

Therefore, it is not called the *Bright Pearl*, but the *Xuanzhu* [Mysterious Pearl].
Just as the most exalted Sage-Teacher Confucius said:
*"That which transcends form is called the Dao/Way;
that which is within form is called instruments."*

And the Supreme Old Ancestor [Laozi] proclaimed:
*"Look inward to the heart—
the heart has no heart;
look outward to the form—
the form has no form."*

Disciples,
this is the fundamental truth of ultimate reality.
Sages of sages, Daoists of Daoists, Buddhas of Buddhas—
all abide in non-clinging, non-manipulation.

If one clings to forms in practice,
then the Yellow Emperor would have sought the *Xuanzhu* through wisdom,
fasting, and purity—
and yet still failed to obtain it.

Disciples!
The Yellow Emperor lost the *Xuanzhu* and found it through *Wángxiàng*;
ordinary mortals grasp profound truth through the *wu-xin* [heartless] multitude.

I have fully revealed the celestial mechanisms,
unveiled the heart-seal.
Yet you must scrutinize carefully,
guard vigilantly—
lest the *Xuanzhu* be lost in the Red River,
and you never know where to seek it again!

Thus, I admonish the disciples to bow in reverence and listen to the gāthā:

*"A thousand scrolls of Daoist scriptures cannot exhaust it,
one direct pointer reveals it utterly.
I urge you not to dabble in myriad methods—
the Dao/Way lies in the heart, not in books.

Clinging to forms while seeking the Mysterious—
endless delusions arise.
With intent in meditation, one becomes a demon.
Many stray down false paths,
while the straight path stands unchallenged.

The True Person has no form, no shape—
a segment of celestial mechanism displayed everywhere.
Do not grope blindly before your eyes,
nor abandon the true path for side doors."*

At that time, Kunyangzi Putong, having completed his dedication to the assembly, admonished his disciple Shi Shouping to compile the teachings into a written record. He then presented it to the Master of the Precepts for inscription to benefit later generations. The Master of the Precepts replied:

*"No need. Simply pass it down from person to person. After one hundred and seventy years, it shall be established as the* **Jìyuàn Tánjīng** *."*

chunks.original_text: 龙门心法 大清高士全真演教龙门承律第七代昆阳子王常月演 第八代戒弟子施守平纂，第十一代宗裔闵一得订正 卷首 一、心法真言 康熙二年，岁在癸卯，十月之吉，昆阳子说戒于金陵碧苑。 谓凝真子邵守善，扶摇子詹守椿曰：“余自髫年慕道，识透浮生不实，幻境无常，要免轮回，早修至道。 但崆峒虽近，广成子未许相逢； 蓬岛非遥，凡夫身安能得到。 务必远离污染，扫尽尘埃，涤荡心胸，洁涓志虑，消磨结习而俗念如灰，淘汰欲身而妄根截断。 诸缘顿息，俱从戒定中一步步行来； 万虑归空，悉自智慧里一层层看到。 拔得开则孥得定，看得透则忍得来。 是以竖起眉毛，手掣割情刀子； 放开脚步，直登渡世般儿。 翻身则解脱轮回，转念则超离罗网。 悲心不泯，古云自度度他； 慈愿常存，我欲自度度彼。 ” “记得昔年寻真访道，曾参王屋，得遇明师。 上蒙三宝之洪恩，亲闻法宝； 下仗一身之膂力，苦行修身。 皈依无上法王，行持大乘妙道。 当逢盛世，安乐清平，万劫难闻，千生罕见。 敢不阐扬三宝，答报四恩！ 少尽涓埃之愿，聊输方寸之明。 ”
chunks.translated_text:
**The Dragon Gate Heart-Law**
*Compiled by the Pure Perfection Master of the Great Qing, Kunyang Zi Wang Changyue (7th Generation Dragon Gate Preceptor), with the 8th Generation Disciple of Vows, Shi Shouping, and annotated by the 11th Generation Descendant, Min Yide*

**Preface: The True Words of the Heart-Law**

In the year Kangxi 2 (1663), in the month of October, on a favorable day, Kunyang Zi expounded the Precepts at the Jinyin Biyuan [Golden Temple Garden] in Jinling [Nanjing].

To the Concentrated-True Master Shao Shoushan and the Soaring-True Master Zhan Shouchun, he said:

*"Since my youthful years, I have aspired to the Dao, piercing through the illusory nature of mortal life—its emptiness, the impermanence of this phantom realm. To escape the wheel of rebirth, one must early cultivate the Supreme Way.

Yet though Mount Kongtong is near, Guangcheng Zi [Laozi] does not grant an audience;
Though Penglai Island is not distant, how can a common man attain it?

One must resolutely withdraw from defilement, sweep away all dust, purify the heart, and cleanse the will—
until worldly habits crumble like ash,
and the body of desire is purged, severing the roots of delusion.

When all causes cease, one advances step by step through Precept and Meditation;
When all thoughts dissolve, one perceives layer by layer through Wisdom.

To break free is to attain steadiness;
To see through is to endure.

Thus, raise the brows like blades—
wield the knife that severs attachment;
take bold strides—
ascend the path of world-transcendence.

Turn the body, and escape the wheel;
shift the mind, and break free from the net.

If compassion does not fade, as the ancients said: 'First save oneself, then others';
If benevolent resolve endures, I wish to save myself—then save all beings."*

*"I recall my past search for Truth and the Dao:
I visited Wangwu Mountain and met a wise teacher.
Above, I received the boundless grace of the Three Jewels,
and personally heard the Dharma-Treasure.
Below, I relied on my own strength,
enduring hardship to refine the body.

I took refuge in the Supreme Dharma-King,
and walked the Path of the Great Vehicle’s perfection.

Now in this flourishing age of peace and ease—
an era rare in ten thousand kalpas, scarce in a thousand lifetimes—
how dare I not proclaim the Three Jewels,
and repay the Four Debts of Gratitude!

Let me fulfill even a drop of dust’s worth of aspiration,
and offer this humble measure of clarity."*

chunks.original_text: “是以不忘僭妄之愆，开坛说戒； 莫避笑讥之谤，演教谈经。 非关好事沽名，只为辟邪解惑。 天律不容绮语，至道惟在直言。 谨将龙门第七代家风，告诸大众。 敬录碧苑一腔直话，普利人天。 不敢虚文，何妨直说。 今将授汝，正以接引愚迷，阐明正法。 ” “若夫上乘法器，明眼高人，则贫道下风有幸，正欲请慈领教，以印证其所闻，贫道之愿也。 ” 子闻是训已，作礼而退，东西序立。 于是广陵弟子施守平稽首颂曰：“法原无法因心有，心本无心为法空。 心现法王心现相，法皈心主法皈空。 要明定法非圆相，须悟凡心即圣心。 心法法心心法法，法心解脱是知音。 ” 二、皈依三宝 三宝者，道经师也。 道本虚空，无形无名，非经不可以明道。 道在经中，幽深微妙，非师不能得其理。 若不皈依三宝，必致沈沦邪道，颠倒昏迷。 凡修真学道之士，志心皈命者，须作难得遭逢之想。 第一皈依无上道宝，当愿众生，常侍天尊，永脱轮回。 第二皈依无上经宝，当愿众生，生生世世，得闻正法。 第三皈依无上师宝，当愿众生，学最上乘，不落邪见。 此三皈依，乃昔之圣贤，度人入道，第一步上升之路，第一重入德之门。 成仙成道，成圣成贤，莫不从此，三皈依起首。 何以故？ 盖性命生死，大事因缘，微妙秘密，难可见闻。 最上乘解脱妙法，若无师真垂慈开示，引诱灵机，安能顿悟大乘正宗，渐入虚无妙道，而不致堕落邪见，错入旁门也耶。 所以未能明道之士，先皈依经。 未能明经，先皈依师。 若能皈依师宝，则经宝可闻于不闻之中。 能闻经宝，则道宝可见于不见之际。 昔日之不可见闻者，一旦豁然贯通，皆由皈依师宝之力也。 自然解悟真文，得明正法，超脱生死，不落轮回。 但我所说皈依三宝法门，须要皈依真三宝。 何以故？ 大众！
chunks.translated_text:
“Thus, I do not forget the transgressions of presumption and arrogance, and open the hall to expound the precepts;
I do not shun the slander of ridicule and mockery, and expound teachings and scriptures.
This is not for the sake of seeking fame through good deeds,
but to dispel evil and resolve doubts.
Heaven’s law brooks no idle words,
and the Supreme Dao lies only in plain speech.

I now solemnly convey the seventh-generation family tradition of the Dragon Gate lineage
to all assembled.
With reverence, I record the unvarnished truth of the Jade Garden,
for the benefit of all beings in heaven and earth.
I dare not indulge in empty rhetoric—
so let me speak plainly.

Today, I impart this to you,
truly to guide the lost and illuminate the true Dharma.”

*“As for those of the highest vehicle—enlightened ones with keen insight—
I am fortunate to be in their presence,
and earnestly request their compassionate instruction,
to verify what I have heard.
This is my sincere wish.”*

Upon hearing these words, the Master bowed and withdrew, standing to the east and west.
Then, the disciple from Guangling, Shi Shouping, knelt and chanted:

“The source of Dharma is without Dharma, yet the mind creates its cause;
The mind is without mind, yet Dharma is emptiness.
When the mind manifests the Dharma-King’s mind, it manifests form;
When the mind takes refuge in Dharma, it takes refuge in emptiness.
To truly understand Dharma’s essence is not to cling to its roundness,
One must awaken to the fact that the ordinary mind is the sacred mind.
Mind and Dharma, Dharma and mind—
When mind and Dharma are resolved, liberation is known.”

**II. Taking Refuge in the Three Jewels**

The Three Jewels are the Dao, the scriptures, and the teacher.
The Dao is originally formless and nameless, the void itself—
without scriptures, it cannot be made clear.
The Dao resides within the scriptures, profound and subtle—
without a teacher, its principles cannot be grasped.
If one does not take refuge in the Three Jewels,
one will surely sink into heretical paths,
lost in inversion and delusion.

All who aspire to cultivate the True Dao and seek the Way
must, with sincere resolve, take refuge.
They should cherish this rare encounter as a precious opportunity.

First, take refuge in the Jewel of the Supreme Dao,
and pray that all beings may forever attend the Celestial Sovereign,
eternally freed from the wheel of rebirth.

Second, take refuge in the Jewel of the Supreme Scripture,
and pray that all beings may, life after life,
hear the true Dharma.

Third, take refuge in the Jewel of the Supreme Teacher,
and pray that all beings may study the highest vehicle,
and never fall into erroneous views.

These Three Refuges are the first step upward taken by ancient sages
to guide others into the Way,
the first gate of virtue through which one enters.

To become an immortal, to attain the Dao,
to become a sage or a worthy—
all begin with these Three Refuges.
Why?
Because the nature of life and death, the great matters of existence,
are subtle and mysterious, unseen and unheard.
The supreme vehicle of liberation and wondrous Dharma—
if not for a true teacher’s compassionate guidance,
who could suddenly awaken to the true teachings of the Great Vehicle,
gradually entering the boundless Dao,
and avoid falling into heresy or straying into false paths?

Thus, those who have not yet understood the Dao must first take refuge in the scriptures.
Those who have not yet understood the scriptures must first take refuge in the teacher.
If one takes refuge in the Jewel of the Teacher,
then the Jewel of the Scripture may be heard where it was not heard before.
If one hears the Jewel of the Scripture,
then the Jewel of the Dao may be seen where it was not seen before.
What was once unseen and unheard suddenly becomes clear—
all through the power of taking refuge in the Jewel of the Teacher.

Thus, one naturally awakens to the true text,
understands the true Dharma,
transcends birth and death,
and escapes the wheel of rebirth.

But the path of taking refuge in the Three Jewels that I speak of
must be in the true Three Jewels.
Why?
O assembled ones!

chunks.original_text: 如今三皈依视为泛常，早晚在圣像之前，日诵礼拜而已，并不曾嚼破皈依端的，为何而来。 故尔毕竞沈迷邪法，不免轮回。 如何得明大道，得脱生死哉！ 〈谢氏按：上两段乃理上事。 〉 所说皈依三宝者。 皈依意，使念无生灭，则道宝可得而明； 皈依心，使机无障碍，则经宝可得而悟； 皈依身，使眼无见，闻无闻，臭无嗅，舌无尝、手无妄动、足无妄行，不染邪淫巧浊，躬行苦行，劳其筋骨，饿其肌肤，惰其肢体，舍其形骸，则师宝可得而感矣。 〈谢氏按：所谓皈依意、心、身三宝者，已是实际功法。 丹道初步若能皈依意自然真士生，皈依心而真火现，皈依身而身不动而精固真水生。 丹道初功就在于水源清浊，水源清浊最大关键有二。 一、身不妄动则水清，身妄动则水浊； 二、火清则水清，火浊水亦浊。 所以皈依身，皈依心，自然筑基不难。 而三宝皆皈依者，功夫更能层层递进。 〉有能感动师慈，传经授道者，必自己皈依自己之身心意，为真三宝也。 我身之耳目，未能忘其见闻，非迷于色，即着于空。 声色尚存，则身非真矣。 非真何以感师？
chunks.translated_text:
Nowadays, the Three Refuges are treated as mere convention—morning and evening before the sacred images, one merely recites and pays homage, without ever truly penetrating the essence of taking refuge. Why then does one come? Thus, one ultimately remains mired in heretical teachings and cannot escape the cycle of rebirth. How then can one attain the Great Dao and transcend birth and death?

*(She Shi’s note: The above two sections concern matters of principle.)*

Those who speak of taking refuge in the Three Jewels must do so in truth. Taking refuge in **intention (意)**, one cultivates the thought of impermanence, and thus the Jewel of the Dao may be illuminated. Taking refuge in **mind (心)**, one removes all obstructions, and thus the Jewel of the Scripture may be awakened. Taking refuge in **body (身)**, one renders the eyes blind to sight, the ears deaf to sound, the nose insensitive to scent, the tongue unable to taste, the hands restrained from movement, and the feet from wandering—untainted by lust, deceit, or impurity—practicing austerities, laboring the sinews, starving the flesh, weakening the limbs, and abandoning the physical form. Only then may one truly invoke the Jewel of the Teacher.

*(She Shi’s note: What is meant by taking refuge in intention, mind, and body are already practical methods. In the initial stages of the Dao of the Elixir, if one takes refuge in intention, the True Gentleman (真士) naturally arises; if one takes refuge in mind, True Fire manifests; if one takes refuge in body, the body remains still while True Water emerges. The foundation of the Dao of the Elixir lies in the purity of the water source, and its greatest key lies in two things: one, if the body does not move recklessly, the water is pure; if the body moves recklessly, the water is turbid; two, if the fire is pure, the water is pure, but if the fire is turbid, the water is also turbid. Thus, taking refuge in the body and in the mind naturally makes foundation-building effortless. And when all three Jewels are taken as refuge, the practice can progress layer by layer.)*

If one can move the Teacher’s compassion and receive transmission of the Scripture and the Dao, it must be through taking refuge in one’s own body, mind, and intention as the true Three Jewels. My own ears and eyes have not yet forgotten their seeing and hearing—whether lost in the illusions of form or attached to emptiness. So long as sound and color remain, the body is not true. How then can it invoke the Teacher?
